column3: When she stood face to face with him she swayed and almost fell.

column2: Virginia went with this man passively--to an appointment which, but an hour ago, she had promised herself she would not keep.
column3: Virginia went with this man passively-to an appointment which, but an hour ago, she had promised herself she would not keep.

column2: Her inmost soul was stirred, just as before.
column3: Her inmost soul was stirred, just as before.

column2: Then it had been few words, now it was a little common song.
column3: Then it had been few words, now it was a little common song.

column2: But the strange power of the man held her close, so she realized that for the moment at least she would do as he desired.
column3: But the strange power of the man held her close, so she realized that for the moment at least she would do as he desired.

column2: In the amazement and consternation of this thought she found time to offer up a little prayer: "Dear God, make him kind to me."
column3: In the amazement and consternation of this thought she found time to offer up a little prayer: "Dear God, make him kind to me."

column2: They leaned against the old bronze guns, facing the river.
column3: They leaned against the old bronze guns, facing the river.

column2: He pulled her shawl about her, masterfully yet with gentleness, and then, as though it was the most natural thing in the world, he drew her to him until she rested against his shoulder.
column3: He pulled her shawl about her, masterfully yet with gentleness, and then, as though it was the most natural thing in the world, he drew her to him until she rested against his shoulder.

column2: And she remained there, trembling, in suspense, glancing at him quickly, in birdlike, pleading glances, as though praying him to be kind.
column3: And she remained there, trembling, in suspense, glancing at him quickly, in birdlike, pleading glances, as though praying him to be kind.

column2: He took no notice after that, so the act seemed less like a caress than a matter of course.
column3: He took no notice after that, so the act seemed less like a caress than a matter of course.

column2: He began to talk, half-humorously, and little by little, as he went on, she forgot her fears, even her feeling of strangeness, and fell completely under the spell of his power.
column3: He began to talk, half humorously, and little by little, as he went on, she forgot her fears, even her feeling of strangeness, and fell completely under the spell of his power.

column2: My name is Ned Trent, he told her, "and I am from Quebec.
column3: My name is Ned Trent, he told her, "and I am from Quebec.

column2: I am a woods runner.
column3: I am a woods runner.

column2: I have journeyed far.
column3: I have journeyed far.

column2: I have been to the uttermost ends of the North, even up beyond the Hills of Silence."
column3: I have been to the uttermost ends of the North, even up beyond the Hills of Silence."

column2: And then, in his gay, half-mocking, yet musical voice he touched lightly on vast and distant things.
column3: And then, in his gay, half mocking, yet musical voice he touched lightly on vast and distant things.

column2: He talked of the great Saskatchewan, of Peace River, and the delta of the Mackenzie, of the winter journeys beyond Great Bear Lake into the Land of the Little Sticks, and the half-mythical lake of Yamba Tooh.
column3: He talked of the great Saskatchewan, of Peace River, and the delta of the Mackenzie, of the winter journeys beyond Great Bear Lake into the Land of the Little Sticks, and the half mythical lake of Yamba Tooh.

column2: He spoke of life with the Dog Ribs and Yellow Knives, where the snow falls in midsummer.
column3: He spoke of life with the Dog Ribs and Yellow Knives, where the snow falls in midsummer.

column2: Before her eyes slowly spread, like a panorama, the whole extent of the great North, with its fierce, hardy men, its dreadful journeys by canoe and sledge, its frozen barrens, its mighty forests, its solemn charm.
column3: Before her eyes slowly spread, like a panorama, the whole extent of the great North, with its fierce, hardy men, its dreadful journeys by canoe and sledge, its frozen barrens, its mighty forests, its solemn charm.

column2: All at once this post of Conjuror's House, a month in the wilderness as it was, seemed very small and tame and civilized for the simple reason that Death did not always compass it about.
column3: All at once this post of Conjuror's House, a month in the wilderness as it was, seemed very small and tame and civilized for the simple reason that Death did not always compass it about.

column2: It was very cold then, said Ned Trent, "and very hard.
column3: It was very cold then, said Ned Trent, "and very hard.

column2: _Le grand frete_[A] of winter had come.
column3: underscore Le grand frete underscore[A] of winter had come.

column2: At night we had no other shelter than our blankets, and we could not keep a fire because the spruce burned too fast and threw too many coals.
column3: At night we had no other shelter than our blankets, and we could not keep a fire because the spruce burned too fast and threw too many coals.

column2: For a long time we shivered, curled up on our snow-shoes; then fell heavily asleep, so that even the dogs fighting over us did not awaken us.
column3: For a long time we shivered, curled up on our snow shoes; then fell heavily asleep, so that even the dogs fighting over us did not awaken us.

column2: Two or three times in the night we boiled tea.
column3: Two or three times in the night we boiled tea.

column2: We had to thaw our moccasins each morning by thrusting them inside our shirts.
column3: We had to thaw our moccasins each morning by thrusting them inside our shirts.

column2: Even the Indians were shivering and saying, 'Ed-sa, yazzi ed-sa'--'it is cold, very cold.' And when we came to Rae it was not much better.
column3: Even the Indians were shivering and saying, 'Ed sa, yazzi ed sa'--'it is cold, very cold.' And when we came to Rae it was not much better.

column2: He said little of himself, but as he went on in short, curt sentences the picture grew more distinct, and to Virginia the man became more and more prominent in it.
column3: He said little of himself, but as he went on in short, curt sentences the picture grew more distinct, and to Virginia the man became more and more prominent in it.

column2: She saw the dying and exhausted dogs, the frost-rimed, weary men; she heard the quick _crunch, crunch, crunch_ of the snow-shoes hurrying ahead to break the trail; she felt the cruel torture of the _mal de raquette_, the shrivelling bite of the frost, the pain of snow blindness, the hunger that yet could not stomach the frozen fish nor the hairy, black caribou meat.
